title: Hidden Emissions & Data Gaps
excerpt: Why military emissions are often missing from climate targets — and what that means for accountability and global climate reporting.
content: Military greenhouse gas emissions are frequently under-reported or excluded from national inventories. This is not just a technical oversight: classification, security concerns and political incentives can reduce transparency.

During war, measurement becomes even harder. Fuel use, overseas operations, supply chains, and the emissions linked to destruction and reconstruction are rarely captured in a consistent way across countries.

A practical improvement would be standardised reporting frameworks that include aggregate fuel-use data, common accounting rules for overseas deployments, and explicit treatment of reconstruction emissions.

sources.label: SGR & CEOBS (2022) Estimating the Military’s Global GHG Emissions

title: Fibre-Optic Drone Cables: A New War Waste
excerpt: Fibre-optic FPV drones can leave kilometres of cable across fields — creating a new stream of conflict-related plastic waste.
content: Fibre-optic guided FPV drones reduce jamming risk by using a cable connection rather than a purely radio-based link. In practice, this can leave long lengths of cable spread across terrain after missions.

These cables are typically polymer-coated and can persist for long periods, fragmenting over time and adding to microplastic pollution. They also create practical hazards for wildlife, farming, and post-conflict clean-up.
This emerging waste stream highlights how new battlefield technologies can generate environmental impacts that are not captured by conventional emissions accounting.

sources.label: CEOBS – Conflict and Environment Observatory (background on conflict pollution)

title: War and Carbon Accounting: The Emissions We Do Not Measure
excerpt: Modern warfare generates vast emissions, yet military carbon accounting remains fragmented, inconsistent, and politically sensitive.
content: War is rarely discussed in climate negotiations, yet modern militaries are among the most energy-intensive institutions on Earth. Jet fuel consumption, armored vehicle operations, naval deployments and global logistics chains all generate significant greenhouse gas emissions. However, these emissions are often under-reported or inconsistently accounted for in national climate targets.

One of the core issues is transparency. Military data is frequently classified, aggregated, or excluded from public reporting frameworks. This creates a structural blind spot in global carbon accounting. When states report their national emissions, military activities conducted overseas or embedded within supply chains may not be fully included. As a result, official figures may underestimate the true climate impact of sustained military operations.

Beyond direct fuel use, war produces secondary emissions that are rarely quantified. The destruction of infrastructure — power plants, factories, housing and transport systems — leads to massive reconstruction efforts. Cement, steel, and industrial rebuilding generate an additional wave of emissions that can last years or even decades after active conflict ends. These indirect impacts blur the line between immediate wartime emissions and long-term climate consequences.

There is also the question of opportunity cost. Military expenditure diverts financial and technological resources that could otherwise be invested in renewable energy, climate adaptation, or resilience infrastructure. In this sense, the environmental cost of war extends beyond measurable emissions; it reshapes policy priorities and delays climate mitigation efforts.

Improving accountability does not require compromising national security. Aggregate reporting frameworks, standardized fuel-use disclosures, and independent environmental monitoring could enhance transparency without revealing sensitive operational details. If climate agreements are to reflect reality, they must acknowledge that conflict and militarization are not climate-neutral activities.

sources.label: SGR & CEOBS (2022) Estimating the Military’s Global GHG Emissions
